David Irving Arrested in Austria
 
 THE historian David Irving has been arrested while on a one-day visit to Vienna. An expert on Hitler's Third Reich, he had been invited by courageous students to address an ancient University association in the Austrian capital.
 
 http://www.nationalvanguard.org/story.php?id=6917
 
 http://www.guardian.co.uk/secondworldwar/story/0,14058,1645409,00.html
 
 http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4446646.stm
 
 Irving Faces Twenty Years in Austrian Prison
 
 World War II expert and revisionist historian David Irving is facing a whopping twenty years in an Austrian prison for speaking, it was announced today (November 17, 2005). Such a sentence could amount to life in prison, as Mr. Irving is in his mid-sixties.
 
 Irving was detained on a 1989 warrant alleging that he violated the Alpine nation's draconian hate laws, which makes even discussion of the extent of the Jewish "holocaust" a crime.
 
 Continued:
 
 http://www.nationalvanguard.org/story.php?id=6927

"Holocaust Denial" Laws Are Disgraceful!
 
 DAVID IRVING, the controversial British historian, was arrested in Austria on November 11 for a 16-year-old violation of that country's "Holocaust denial" statute. He has now been formally charged, and if found guilty could face years in prison.
 
 His case is by no means unique. In Germany, France, Austria, Belgium, Switzerland and several other European countries, as well as in Israel, it is a crime publicly to dispute the official version of Holocaust history.
 
 The list of those who have been fined, imprisoned, or forced into exile for "denying the Holocaust" includes Robert Faurisson and Roger Garaudy in France, Siegfried Verbeke in Belgium, Juergen Graf and Gaston-Armand Amaudruz in Switzerland, and Guenter Deckert, Hans Schmidt and Fredrick Toben in Germany.

There is a specific exemption in the European convention on human rights, excluding holocaust denial and promotion of nazi-type ideologies. The holocaust has a particular importance because its denial is synonymous with the promotion of Nazism, as Irving illustrates nicely. Whether such denial should be illegal is a different matter, I'm unsure, it doesn't seem to have much effect on Nazism in Austria as opposed to the UK, though that could be as much because a British nationalism takes fighting the Nazis as one of its core doctrines, whereas Austria and Germany have nationalism associated with Nazism, which may make it easier for reltaively harmless nationalism to be channeled into Nazism.

 The Austrian Treaty of Vienna 1955 contains regulations about human rights, Austrians borders and an article about the annulment of all nazi organisations:
 
 Article 9, Austrian Treaty of Vienna 1955:
 1. Austria will accomplish the already passed, appropriate and of the allied commision for Austria allowed, laws started measures to abolish the nationalsocialistic party and its associated and controlled organisations including the political, military and paramilitary organisations on austrian territory.
 Austria will also continue its efforts to abscise all hints of nazism out of austrians political, economical and cultural life, to assure that none of the above-named organisations are able to originate again in any form, and to avoid all nazistic or military activity and propaganda in Austria.
 
 2. Austria pledges itself to abolish all fascistic organisations, which exist on its territory, as well political, military and paramilitary as all other organisations, which display any hostile action against the united nations or which want to bereave the democratic rights of the population.
 
 3. Austria pledges itself to forbid the existance and the actions of the above-named organisation on Austrian territory, on pain of penalties, which have to be fixed immediatly according to Austrian laws.
